awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Cardiac Ischemia On-a-Chip: Probing Mechanisms Underlying Molecular, Cellular and Tissue-Level Adaptive Responses After Injury
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Nikkhah, Mehdi
Proposal No: 1653193

Heart attack (Myocardial infarction) is a leading cause of death, but its underlying biological mechanisms are not well understood. In this work, a novel well-designed experimental study is proposed with cells from the heart (cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts) with the associated biological and structural features for uncovering the underlying biological mechanisms. Successful completion of the project will result in an improved understanding of what causes heart diseases. The educational and outreach of this CAREER program have been designed to benefit high school teachers and stimulate long-term interest in K-12 students towards science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).

Cardiac ischemia, including acute myocardial infarction (MI, ?heart attack?) and chronic ischemic heart disease (chronic IHD), are highly progressive biological disorders that can ultimately lead to catastrophic heart failure and death. Hypoxia has been implicated as the major regulator of ischemia-induced cardiac injury, through triggering of a multitude of molecular and cellular signaling cascades, leading to contractile dysfunction and adverse remodeling of the myocardium. While the pathophysiological responses of the heart, specifically during MI, have been the subject of intensive studies using gold standard animal models, the lack of precise control over the microenvironmental cues and the inability to fully recapitulate human physiology have led to a major knowledge gap in biological understating of ischemia-induced cardiac injury. This CAREER program aims to meet the critical need for the development of an alternative platform technology that addresses the limitations of current in vitro assays and has translational advantages over animal models. The goal of this five-year program is to develop a native-like three dimensional (3D) myocardial tissue model on-a-chip and mimic ischemia induced cardiac diseased conditions to provide a fundamental framework on the underlying complex biological and pathophysiological events following injury.  Insights derived are expected to open new avenues for the development of enabling technologies to elucidate molecular and cellular mechanisms governing ischemic heart disease. Additionally, the proposed study has the potential to advance multimodal pharmacological based therapies for repair and regeneration of the heart in particular, and other complex organs/tissues, in general. The educational and outreach of this CAREER program have been designed to benefit high school teachers and stimulate long-term interest in K-12 students towards science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). The proposed initiatives will also provide interdisciplinary training for the next generation of undergraduate and graduate students in STEM fields. Furthermore, this CAREER program will bring collaborative synergy among bioengineering scientists and clinicians in cardiovascular medicine.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF CAREER project titled “Cardiac Ischemia On-a-Chip: Probing Mechanisms Underlying Molecular, Cellular and Tissue-Level Adaptive Responses After Injury” was aimed toward the development of a physiologically relevant myocardium tissue on-a-chip model (i.e., Heart on-a-chip) using the techniques of microengineering and cardiac biology to study the biological mechanisms of cardiovascular diseases, (e.g., Heart Attack).


In the first phase of this project, we developed an innovative anisotropic 3D microfluidic cardiac tissue on-a-chip model, referred to as a heart on-a-chip. We utilized both rat-derived cardiomyocytes and human pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (hPSC-CMs) to better mimic the native myocardium. This was achieved through co-culturing with interstitial cells, specifically cardiac fibroblasts (CFs), biomimetic collagen hydrogel encapsulation, and the induction of highly anisotropic tissue architecture. This unique arrangement resulted in the formation of physiologically relevant cardiac tissues with resembling the native myocardium. After two weeks of culture, the cardiac tissue within the chip exhibited well-defined sarcomeric striations, highly synchronous contractions, and a notable upregulation of several maturation genes. These findings demonstrated the capability of the engineered heart on-a-chip platform as a novel tool for cardiac disease modeling and therapeutic testing.

 

Within the second phase of this project, we further utilized the capabilities of the developed heart on-a-chip model for advanced cardiac disease modeling. Specifically, we developed a model of myocardial ischemia on-a-chip, recapitulating ischemic insult by exposing the mature 3D cardiac tissues to hypoxic environments. We further performed extensive biological validation, based on cellular and molecular-level analyses, to demonstrate the utility of the proposed model in successfully recapitulating myocardial ischemia (i.e., Heart Attack). This involved: 1) Induction of tissue fibrosis through the upregulation of contractile fibers; 2) Dysregulation in tissue contraction; 3) Upregulation of hypoxia-response genes and downregulation of contractile-specific genes; 4) Transcriptomic pathway regulation of hypoxic tissues; and 4) Cell toxicity in response to ischemia-reperfusion injury. These findings showcased the effectiveness of our heart attack on-a-chip model in accurately simulating myocardial ischemia from molecular changes to functional consequences.

 

In the final phase of this project, we achieved a groundbreaking milestone by successfully developing a 3D Long QT syndrome type 2 (LQTS2) tissue on-a-chip for the first time. This was accomplished using our heart-on-chip microfluidic technology, 3D hydrogel biomaterials, and a co-culture of gene edited isogenic hiPSC-CMs and hiPSC-CFs. We initially created hiPSC line with an R531W mutation in KCNH2, a mutation associated with the onset of LQTS2, utilizing a novel CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing technique. We then successfully differentiated and characterized isogenic CMs and CFs from both wild-type (WT) and KCNH2-edited hiPSCs. A deficiency in hERG trafficking was identified in hiPSC-CMs with the KCNH2 mutation, shedding light on a potential mechanism for the pathophysiology of LQTS2 associated with the R531W mutation. Furthermore, we conducted extensive characterization of the LQTS2 tissue on-a-chip, including analysis of tissue structure, contractile function, calcium handling, and β-agonist response. To explore potential therapeutic interventions, we attempted phenotypic rescue through the application of various pharmaceutical agents. This comprehensive approach not only demonstrates the successful creation and characterization of a novel LQTS2 tissue on-a-chip but also provides a platform for exploring potential therapeutic strategies for this cardiac disorder. In conjunction with these significant initiatives, this award alos enabled us to cultivate isogenic cardiac organoids under serum starvation conditions by employing a co-culture approach with hiPSC-CMs and hiPSC-CFs. The cardiac organoids underwent thorough characterization through morphological assessment, evaluation of cellular ultrastructures, and analysis of transcriptomic and electrophysiological profiles.


In total, this NSF CAREER award resulted in the publication of 8 high-impact articles, which were featured in prestigious journals such as "Science Advances" and "Biomaterials". Additionally, numerous conference abstracts and presentations were delivered at national and international conferences, including the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES). Furthermore, the research initiative led to the submission of one invention disclosure.


Regarding educational activities, this project played a pivotal role in training the next generation of graduate and undergraduate students. Through this grant, the PI mentored 2 PhD students (female, Hispanic), 2 postdoctoral fellows (female, African American), and 3 undergraduate students (two female). Both PhD students successfully defended their PhD dissertations, received the prestigious "Dean’s Dissertation Award”, and secured excellent postdoctoral fellowship and industry positions. All students gained extensive experience in human stem cell culture, differentiation, and establishing 3D tissues on-a-chip. Concurrently, the students participated in scientific writing by preparing journal articles. The students were also given the opportunity to present their work at numerous national-level conferences, including BMES, ASU Regenerative Medicine and FURI symposiums. In parallel, the students engaged in outreach and educational activities every year, such as Night of Open Door, Summer Engineering Experience, and Grand Scholar Challenge (GCSP). The comprehensive educational activities conducted during this project contributed significantly to the professional development and success of the mentored students.Furthermore, the PI (Nikkhah) incorporated the outcomes of this study into his graduate-level course "Biomedical Microdevices" and delivered multiple invited seminars.
